comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: Born circa 1889 Tom was the son of the late John & Mary Ann Brown of Longsight, Manchester. www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/544526/BROWN,%20TOM (Listed as Tom Brown so I do not think he is Thomas Frederick as Gary surmises, and always shown in the census returns as Tom). "D" Coy. 10th Bn. attd. 7th Bn. In 1891 the Browns lived at 12 Whiley St, Rusholme, Manchester. John Brown was a 37yr old Railway Clerk and he and his wife had 3 children. maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&psj=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc... By 1901 John Brown had died and Mary had moved with her 4 children to 597 Stockport Road, Longsight where she was running a Grocer's shop. At the time of the 1911 census Tom was described as "Student Science" and still living at 597 Stockport Rd where his widowed mother now had a Wine & Spirits shop. The family occupied six rooms. The above information via www.cwgc.org and www.ancestry.co.uk

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
The attack on Grandcourt on the opening day of the Battle of the Ancre, 13th November 1916, was a defining moment in the brief history of 7th Battalion the East Lancashire Regiment.  The Battalion had already seen action on the Somme during the Battle of Albert at La Boiselle; in the attacks on High Wood; and during the Battles for Pozierres and the Ancre Heights.  This final act in the Battle of the Somme, the attack into German positions astride the Ancre tributary was made across waterlogged ground, pounded by artillery and defended in depth.

10th Battalion East Lancashires was a Reserve battalion, holding trained reinforcements in the UK.  In 1915 it was based from April in Swanage until August 1915 when it moved to Wareham in Dorset.  

7th (Service) Battalion The East Lancashire Regiment was a K2 battalion, in 56th Brigade of 19th (Western) Division (the Butterfly Division).  56th Brigade comprised four battalions: 7th King's Own; 7th East Lancs; 7th South Lancs; and 7th Loyal North Lancs; supported by 56th MG Coy and 56th Trench Mortar Bty.  Many of the soldiers in the original 7th East Lancs battalion came from the Preston area.  The Battalion had arrived in France in July 1915.

Second Lieutenant Tom Brown was 26 years old when he was killed.  (Possibly Frederick Tom Brown, born Chorley, Manchester, 1890).  His parents are listed by the CWGC as '... the late John and Mary Brown of Longsight, Manchester.'  He is also commemorated on the Manchester University 1914-18 War Memorial.//
